extracted_concepts.definition: Any ground that impedes movement, making it harder to traverse.

rule_logic.premise: A creature moves through an area of difficult terrain
rule_logic.implication: Every 1 foot of movement costs 2 feet
rule_logic.description_text: Every foot of movement in difficult terrain costs 1 extra foot. This rule is true even if multiple things in an area create difficult terrain, the cost is not cumulative.

extracted_concepts.definition: Maneuvering through a space occupied by another creature.

rule_logic.premise: A creature moves through the space of a non-hostile creature
rule_logic.implication: The space counts as difficult terrain for the moving creature
rule_logic.description_text: You can move through a nonhostile creature's space. In contrast, you can move through a hostile creature's space only if the creature is at least two Sizes larger or smaller than you. Remember that another creature's space is difficult terrain for you.

extracted_concepts.concept_name: Cannot End Move in Hostile Creature's Space
extracted_concepts.definition: A restriction on ending movement within a hostile creature's occupied area.

rule_logic.premise: A creature attempts to end its movement in a hostile creature's space
rule_logic.implication: The creature cannot willingly end its move there
rule_logic.description_text: Whether a creature is an ally or an enemy, you can't willingly end your move in its space.

extracted_concepts.definition: Specialized movement types that alter movement cost.

rule_logic.premise: A creature is climbing, swimming, or crawling
rule_logic.implication: Every 1 foot of movement costs 2 feet
exceptions: A creature with a climbing speed ignores this extra cost for climbing
A creature with a swimming speed ignores this extra cost for swimming
rule_logic.description_text: Every foot of movement while climbing, swimming, or crawling costs 1 extra foot (2 feet per foot moved) unless a creature has a climbing or swimming speed.

extracted_concepts.definition: The action of changing from the prone condition to standing.

rule_logic.premise: A prone creature wishes to stand up
rule_logic.implication: Cost is half of the creature's movement speed
exceptions: Cannot stand up if speed is 0
rule_logic.description_text: You can drop prone without using any of your speed. Standing up takes an amount of movement equal to half your speed. For example, if your speed is 30 feet, you must spend 15 feet of movement to stand up. You can't stand up if you don't have enough movement left or if your speed is 0.

extracted_concepts.definition: The act of moving a character or monster during its turn in combat, utilizing their available speed.

rule_logic.premise: It is your turn
rule_logic.implication: You can move a distance up to your speed, using as much or as little as desired.
rule_logic.description_text: On your turn, you can move a distance up to your speed. You can use as much or as little of your speed as you like on your turn, following the rules here.

extracted_concepts.definition: The ability to integrate various modes of movement (such as walking, jumping, climbing, and swimming) within a single turn's movement allowance.

rule_logic.premise: Character is moving during their turn AND Character uses different modes of movement (e.g., jumping, climbing, swimming, walking)
rule_logic.implication: These modes can be combined, or one mode can constitute the entire move. The distance of each part of the move is deducted from total speed until speed is used or movement is done.
rule_logic.description_text: Your movement can include jumping, climbing, and swimming. These different modes of movement can be combined with walking, or they can constitute your entire move. However you're moving, you deduct the distance of each part of your move from your speed until it is used up or until you are done moving.

extracted_concepts.definition: The ability to divide a character's total movement allowance on their turn, performing some movement before an action and some after.

rule_logic.premise: On your turn
rule_logic.implication: You can divide your total movement speed allowance across the duration of your turn, moving some distance, taking your action, and then moving the remaining distance.
rule_logic.description_text: You can break up your movement on your turn, using some of your speed before and after your action.
related_search_terms: can I move then attack then move

extracted_concepts.definition: The specific allowance to intersperse movement between individual attacks when an action permits multiple weapon attacks.

rule_logic.premise: You take an action that includes more than one weapon attack
rule_logic.implication: You can move between each individual attack made as part of that action, dividing your total movement speed accordingly.
rule_logic.description_text: If you take an action that includes more than one weapon attack, you can break up your movement even further by moving between those attacks.
related_search_terms: can I move after first attack

extracted_concepts.definition: Rules for combining different movement speeds (e.g., walking, flying) during a single turn's movement.

rule_logic.premise: You have more than one speed (e.g., walking speed and a flying speed)
rule_logic.implication: You can switch between these speeds during your move. When switching, subtract the distance already moved from the new speed to determine remaining movement for that speed type. If remaining movement is 0 or less, the new speed cannot be used further in the current move.
rule_logic.description_text: If you have more than one speed, such as your walking speed and a flying speed, you can switch back and forth between your speeds during your move. Whenever you switch, subtract the distance you've already moved from the new speed. The result determines how much farther you can move. If the result is 0 or less, you can't use the new speed during the current move.

extracted_concepts.definition: Any environment or obstacle that impedes movement, such as boulder-strewn caverns, briar-choked forests, treacherous staircases, low furniture, rubble, undergrowth, steep stairs, snow, or shallow bogs. The space occupied by another creature also counts as difficult terrain.

rule_logic.premise: A creature moves 1 foot through a space considered difficult terrain
rule_logic.implication: That 1 foot of movement costs an additional 1 foot of movement (totaling 2 feet of movement cost). This effect does not stack if multiple difficult terrain sources are present in the same space.
rule_logic.description_text: Every foot of movement in difficult terrain costs 1 extra foot. This rule is true even if multiple things in a space count as difficult terrain.
related_search_terms: how does difficult terrain affect movement

extracted_concepts.definition: A voluntary action taken by a combatant to enter the prone condition.

rule_logic.premise: Player decides to drop prone
rule_logic.implication: Does not use any movement speed
rule_logic.description_text: You can drop prone without using any of your speed.

extracted_concepts.definition: The action of changing from the prone condition to standing.

rule_logic.premise: A creature in the prone condition attempts to stand up
rule_logic.implication: Costs an amount of movement equal to half its speed. Cannot stand up if insufficient movement or speed is 0.
rule_logic.description_text: Standing up takes more effort; doing so costs an amount of movement equal to half your speed. For example, if your speed is 30 feet, you must spend 15 feet of movement to stand up. You can't stand up if you don't have enough movement left or if your speed is 0.

extracted_concepts.definition: The method of moving across a surface while in the prone condition without magical assistance.

rule_logic.premise: A prone creature attempts to move without using magic (e.g., teleportation)
rule_logic.implication: Movement must be by crawling. Every foot of crawling costs 1 extra foot of movement (total 2 feet per 1 foot moved). If crawling in difficult terrain, 1 foot moved costs 3 feet of movement.
rule_logic.description_text: To move while prone, you must crawl or use magic such as teleportation. Every foot of movement while crawling costs 1 extra foot. Crawling 1 foot in difficult terrain, therefore, costs 3 feet of movement.

extracted_concepts.definition: The act of traversing a space occupied by a creature that is not hostile to the moving character.

rule_logic.premise: Character attempts to move through a nonhostile creature's space
rule_logic.implication: Movement is allowed. The nonhostile creature's space is considered difficult terrain for the moving character.
rule_logic.description_text: You can move through a nonhostile creature's space. ... Remember that another creature's space is difficult terrain for you.

extracted_concepts.definition: The act of traversing a space occupied by a creature that is hostile to the moving character.

rule_logic.premise: Character attempts to move through a hostile creature's space AND the hostile creature is at least two sizes larger or smaller than the character
rule_logic.implication: Movement is allowed. The hostile creature's space is considered difficult terrain for the moving character.
exceptions: If the hostile creature is not at least two sizes larger or smaller than the character, movement through its space is not allowed.
rule_logic.description_text: In contrast, you can move through a hostile creature's space only if the creature is at least two sizes larger or smaller than you. ... Remember that another creature's space is difficult terrain for you.

extracted_concepts.concept_name: Ending Move in Another Creature's Space
extracted_concepts.definition: The act of completing a movement action or turn in a space already occupied by another creature.

rule_logic.premise: Character attempts to willingly end their move in another creature's space (whether friend or enemy)
rule_logic.implication: The character cannot do so.
rule_logic.description_text: Whether a creature is a friend or an enemy, you can't willingly end your move in its space.

extracted_concepts.concept_name: Opportunity Attack Provocation (Moving out of reach)
extracted_concepts.definition: A condition that triggers a hostile creature to make an opportunity attack.

rule_logic.premise: Character leaves a hostile creature's reach during their move
rule_logic.implication: The character provokes an opportunity attack from that hostile creature.
exceptions: Opportunity attacks are further explained later in the chapter, suggesting other conditions or ways to prevent them.
rule_logic.description_text: If you leave a hostile creature's reach during your move, you provoke an opportunity attack, as explained later in the chapter.

extracted_concepts.definition: The condition under which a flying creature loses altitude and falls.

rule_logic.premise: Flying creature is knocked prone OR Flying creature's speed is reduced to 0 OR Flying creature is deprived of the ability to move
rule_logic.implication: Creature falls
exceptions: Creature has the ability to hover
Creature is being held aloft by magic (e.g., *fly* spell)
rule_logic.description_text: If a flying creature is knocked prone, has its speed reduced to 0, or is otherwise deprived of the ability to move, the creature falls, unless it has the ability to hover or it is being held aloft by magic, such as by the *fly* spell.

extracted_concepts.definition: The area in feet that a creature effectively controls in combat, distinct from its physical dimensions.

rule_logic.premise: A creature exists in combat
rule_logic.implication: It occupies a designated 'space' (e.g., 5x5 ft for Medium) that it controls, and other creatures generally cannot enter this space unless allowed or by specific rules.
rule_logic.description_text: A creature's space is the area in feet that it effectively controls in combat, not an expression of its physical dimensions. If a Medium hobgoblin stands in a 5-foot-wide doorway, other creatures can't get through unless the hobgoblin lets them.

rule_logic.premise: Creature has Tiny size
rule_logic.implication: Controls a space of '2.5 by 2.5 ft.'
rule_logic.description_text: Tiny creatures control a space of 2.5 by 2.5 ft.

rule_logic.implication: Controls a space of '5 by 5 ft.'
rule_logic.description_text: Small creatures control a space of 5 by 5 ft.

rule_logic.premise: Creature has Medium size
rule_logic.implication: Controls a space of '5 by 5 ft.'
rule_logic.description_text: Medium creatures control a space of 5 by 5 ft.

rule_logic.premise: Creature has Large size
rule_logic.implication: Controls a space of '10 by 10 ft.'
rule_logic.description_text: Large creatures control a space of 10 by 10 ft.

extracted_concepts.definition: A creature of Huge size occupies a 15 by 15 feet area in combat.

rule_logic.premise: Creature has Huge size
rule_logic.implication: Controls a space of '15 by 15 ft.'
rule_logic.description_text: Huge creatures control a space of 15 by 15 ft.

extracted_concepts.definition: A creature of Gargantuan size occupies a 20 by 20 feet area or larger in combat.

rule_logic.premise: Creature has Gargantuan size
rule_logic.implication: Controls a space of '20 by 20 ft. or larger'
rule_logic.description_text: Gargantuan creatures control a space of 20 by 20 ft. or larger.

extracted_concepts.definition: A rule limiting the number of creatures that can effectively surround another creature in combat based on their respective sizes.

rule_logic.premise: Multiple creatures attempt to surround another creature in combat
rule_logic.implication: The number of surrounding creatures is limited by their sizes (e.g., eight Medium creatures can surround a Medium/Small one, fewer larger creatures, more Medium creatures can surround a Gargantuan one).
rule_logic.description_text: A creature's space also reflects the area it needs to fight effectively. For that reason, there's a limit to the number of creatures that can surround another creature in combat. Assuming Medium combatants, eight creatures can fit in a 5-foot radius around another one. Because larger creatures take up more space, fewer of them can surround a creature. If five Large creatures crowd around a Medium or smaller one, there's little room for anyone else. In contrast, as many as twenty Medium creatures can surround a Gargantuan one.
related_search_terms: how many creatures can attack one target

extracted_concepts.definition: A maneuver allowing a creature to move through a space normally designated for a creature one size category smaller than itself.

rule_logic.premise: A creature attempts to move through a space sized for a creature one size category smaller than itself (e.g., Large creature through 5 ft. wide passage)
rule_logic.implication: The creature must spend 1 extra foot of movement for every foot moved within that space, has disadvantage on attack rolls and Dexterity saving throws, and attack rolls against it have advantage.
rule_logic.description_text: A creature can squeeze through a space that is large enough for a creature one size smaller than it. Thus, a Large creature can squeeze through a passage that's only 5 feet wide. While squeezing through a space, a creature must spend 1 extra foot for every foot it moves there, and it has disadvantage on attack rolls and Dexterity saving throws. Attack rolls against the creature have advantage while it's in the smaller space.

extracted_concepts.definition: Simple physical interactions with objects in the environment that can be performed without consuming a full action or significant movement resources, often during movement or as part of another action.

rule_logic.premise: Player wishes to perform a simple, quick interaction with an object (e.g., drawing a weapon, opening a door, picking up a small item, handing an item, throwing a lever).
rule_logic.implication: The player can perform this interaction during their movement or as part of another action, without consuming their primary action for the turn.
rule_logic.description_text: Here are a few examples of the sorts of thing you can do in tandem with your movement and action: draw or sheathe a sword, open or close a door, withdraw a potion from your backpack, pick up a dropped axe, take a bauble from a table, remove a ring from your finger, stuff some food into your mouth, plant a banner in the ground, fish a few coins from your belt pouch, drink all the ale in a flagon, throw a lever or a switch, pull a torch from a sconce, take a book from a shelf you can reach, extinguish a small flame, don a mask, pull the hood of your cloak up and over your head, put your ear to a door, kick a small stone, turn a key in a lock, tap the floor with a 10-foot pole, hand an item to another character.

can i draw my sword and attack
what are my free things to do
